Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 11:10AM fender81 wrote: Sorry, I've never had rads to that area. I was on Tamoxifen while premenopausal. I wanted to add that DVT therapy can be done while on Tamoxifen. I can see that the person who posted had 2 other factors involved so I wanted you to be clear it is a VERY low risk. I had one after my TRAM but my PS never took me off Tamoxifen before my surgery. I then was on lovenox then coumadin while staying on Tamoxifen. My doctors felt if the Tamoxifen is working there is no need to mess with a good thing. As long as you go to have your INR checked regularly, like everyone else on coumadin is supposed to, you can successfully be on both at the same time... I was.
Posts.Title: rads to neck anyone? Tamoxinfen & Stage IV? pattih pattih

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 08:22AM fender81 wrote: Congrats on NED! I usually lurk here but saw your post and think I might have an answer... Recently after a neulasta shot my white count went up to 36K... My next scan (4 weeks later) showed an enlarged spleen. The spleen stores white blood cells so can be enlarged when our bodies are in over drive making them.  (at least that's what I was told:) Certainly confirm this with your medical team and if you have any pain in you're spleen, seek care ASAP. Anne
Posts.Title: Great Scans but Enlarged Spleen Ready2Win BouncingBetties

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 01:25PM fender81 wrote: I hope I didn't get anyone questioning their treatment plan... I think everyone's treatment is tailored to their individual cancer... If you're having a good response to current treatment, I'd stay the course. If you trust your onc, then trust your onc. Sure you should ask questions but their clinical experience may be different than another doctor's.   fyi I ended up leaving that onc after misdiagnosed liver mets that went on for almost 6 months then she sent me for a resection which was way too late... too many lesions to count (multiple abdominal nodes as well). The largest one on my liver had a 29 SUV uptake. She didn't know what to do then. She shared her chemo/AI reasoning in 2008 and I think it may be true. My current onc. does not use both at the same time either. I didn't ask why since I already have an answer that works for me. I'm currently NED (13 months now:) on faslodex/xgeva/avastin.
Posts.Title: How many on AI/chemo at the same time? PJB nancyh

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 10:17AM fender81 wrote: Hi Paula, I had the following explaination from an oncologist who does not use hormonals with chemo: chemo's job is to destroy quckly multiplying cells. Using an AI may in itself slows down the cancer cells. The AI would slow down cells that are there, making them a harder target for the chemo to hit. Made sense to me. Anne
Posts.Title: How many on AI/chemo at the same time? PJB nancyh

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 05:13PM - edited Feb 18, 2011 05:16PM by fender81 Attn: nowords: I would just like to inform you the quick strides made in HIV research were made by Dr. Rudolf Willis. He was the first research scientist to isolate HIV and see the specifics of it. His findings significantly slow down its progression to AIDS. After this discovery, his interest turned to oncology. Know where he works now? The Cancer Treatment Centers of America. I was suppose to die last year according to Dana Farber. I went to Dr. Willis and was close to liver failure but I am here today NED because God sent me to him. Do I believe in a cure? Yes, but not from the research hospitals... they have too much to lose once there's nothing left to research.

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2013 09:48PM - edited Jan 31, 2013 09:49PM by fender81 I've been going to CTCA in Philly since 2008. I went for a second opinion after the chief medical officer (my doctor and internationally exclaimed BC specialist) of Dana Farber told me with his treatment plan I had up to 18 months to live. I recieved treatment at CTCA not offered at DF and came back home to Boston NED. In January 2010 when my cancer came back in my liver, a high profiled onc at Beth Israel in Boston (another Harvard research hosp.) told me I had up to 1 year. I went back to CTCA (where they also found brain mets) had treatment and went back to NED. I had a recurrance of liver and brain mets over the past year and a half which led to Y90 radiation to my liver and a right frontal craniotomy and IMRT but am again back to NED and on afinitor/aromasin. CTCA is in this fight with me. They have been as aggressive as I want them to be and ask for nothing in return. I'm on medicare with a BCBS supplement and have given CTCA $0 out of my own pocket. This thread was started with a negative undertone toward CTCA so I suppose not everyone would fit in here (it's really full of the most positive and happy patients - as well as employees - I have ever seen). It looks as though 7 out of 9 of the comments (all negative) have never actually been to one of their facilities which is usually the case when a conversation about CTCA comes up on-line(not just here but on a lot of forums)  Before my first visit, I was a bit sceptical... they never promised or even mentioned a cure... only that they would fight with me as long as I am able. They have certainly kept their promise with me. Best of luck to you all - Anne

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2013 07:54AM fender81 wrote: I have had liver mets off an on for almost 4 years. I have had a lot of pain with mine. I was told by my IR after theresperes that my mets were close to the surface and that's where all the nerves of the liver are located which is why I feel so much pain. for a few months I had to go on 20mg extended release oxicontin along with 10 mg oxicodone for breakthrough pain while my body broke down the tumors. I also can feel pain when my treatment is working and the tumors are shrinking. I'd ask them for the results.
Posts.Title: Liver mets sypmtoms Evans1128 soleil505

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 01:15PM fender81 wrote: Yes, cancer is too complex to make such a general statement... any general statement, including "it's less aggressive if it's ER/PR+" can be quite misleading. For example, I was dx. ER/PR+ just 5 years ago at the age of 36... I failed Tamoxifen in less then a year, failed Femara in only 7 months, failed Aromasin in 6 WEEKS - I went from 2 small liver lesions to uncountable, all quadrants involved and now into abdominal lymph nodes in 6 weeks (I had switched to aromosin in hopes of staying stable as I awaited a liver resection) and after one year just found out I've failed Faslodex. So yes there are some pretty aggressive ER/PR+ cancers out there. Each person's breast cancer is as individual as each of us regardless of hormone status. - Anne
Posts.Title: does cancer move slower in older women? mkkjd60 fender81

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2013 01:33PM fender81 wrote: From what I understand, the CTC test should be done with other breast cancer specific markers (CA27-29, CA15-3, possibly even CEA) and any trends upward should be cause for concern. In 2010 after I reached NED my CTC was 0. My onc. told me if it got to 5, whether or not my scans were clear, I would go back on chemo. In 2011 a PET showed a liver recurrence and the CTC only went up to 1. I went down to 0 again that november while my tumor showed stable on halaven. Once I showed progression (still on halaven), the next CTC was at 12... I switched chemo and it slowly went down. First to 10, then to 4 and finally back down to 0 - again at that point was NED. So now we know a 1 is significant for me so I will be scanned if I hit 1 again. We use it now as a response to treatment like any other marker.
Posts.Title: Had a circulating tumor cell test done lovinmomma Jac53

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2013 11:43AM fender81 wrote: Hello. I had 4 right frontal mets radiated with SRS in 2010. Had another left occipital met in Dec. 2011 which was successfully radiated. Then in May last year I had a right frontal recurrence and a craniotomy removed 2 tumors followed by IMRT (a different type of radiation) to the tumor bed and 1 unresectable spot. The surgery was on a Wednesday and I was home 2 days later. For me not nearly bad as I imagined. The recovery took about a full month for me to feel back to myself. My right frontal has been clear since. Within the last week we've found a new spot in my right cerebellum and I'm getting SRS this coming Tuesday. My liver also has 4 new spots and we're doing chemoembolization about a week after the rads treatment. I just wanted you to know here is hope after this diagnosis. Faith and prayer have been everything I've needed to get through. Anne
Posts.Title: Update on me - brain surgery scheduled nancyh RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2013 10:52AM fender81 wrote: I'm not HER2 but ER+. 3 years ago my liver was quickly progressing when I switched oncs. My new dr. sent me for a brain MRI. I did not have symptoms but we found 4 small right frontal brain mets which were eligible for SRS. Since then I get an MRI every three months. In Dec. 2011, again without symptoms, a left occipital met popped up... again SRS was used. I also had a recurrance of the right frontal mets last May... no "brain" symptoms (I did have more generalized symptoms of fatigue and nausea but my liver and peritoneal mets were advancing, too) but the largest was 2cm, another was 4mm and both of these were removed through craniotomy... there was another 5mm which was unresectable which I had IMRT to treat the tumor bed and knock the remaining tumor out - it worked) I've never had headaches, dizziness, loss of balance, vision changes, etc. which would be more traditional brain mets symptoms. FYI - I'm currently NED and a big believer in early detection saving lives - even when it comes to mets.
Posts.Title: Brain MRI .. how often .. especially Her2+ gals JeninMichigan lilylady

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 07:11PM fender81 wrote: I just commented on the Cancer Treatment Centers thread re: my extensive liver mets. I went to their facility last March - at which time I was very close to beginning liver failure (my onc. recently told me). I had uncountable mets, highest SUV over 27. I didn't realize how horrible I felt until I started chemo. I felt better than I had in months only 2 weeks into my treatment of xeloda, gemzar and avastin. They use fractionated doses so have less toxicity. My last scan was June 28 and I am NED! There are chemos that will get this under control for you and there are plenty left to try. Don't give up! Anne
